awd_titl_txt: Genesis and Dynamics of very-large-scale Motions in the Atmospheric Boundary Layer and their Interactions with Utility-scale Wind Turbines
awd_abstract_narration:
In wind energy technology, predicting the evolution of wind turbine wakes under different atmospheric conditions is important for optimizing power production from a wind farm and mitigating damaging loads on the turbines due to detrimental wake interactions.  This project aims to investigate the origin, evolution and regeneration of what are called very-large-scale motions (VLSMs) that evolve in the layer of air near the blade surface, termed the atmospheric boundary layer (ABL), and their interactions with utility-scale wind turbines. As the scale of wind farms continues to grow and as wind turbines increase in size, VLSMs are expected to profoundly influence wind power production and the downstream evolution of wind turbine wakes. However, the origin and dynamics of VLSMs are not well understood in some cases, and therefore their effects and interactions with utility-scale wind turbines are difficult to predict. This project advances numerical simulations and proof-of-concept laboratory experiments on this topic.  Additionally, undergraduate students are being trained to measure wind velocities at the University of Texas Dallas mobile LIDAR (Light Imaging, Detection, And Ranging) station, which is a unique facility for education and outreach activities.  This training impact students from a wide range of backgrounds and makes them aware of important topics, such as meteorology, extreme weather phenomena, anthropogenic effects on the environment and renewable energy. 

The goals of this research project are to: 1) better understand the physical mechanisms generating VLSMs and their variability as a consequence of the daily cycle of atmospheric stability, different topography and land cover; 2) explore how VLSMs affect downstream evolution of wakes produced by utility-scale wind turbines; 3) develop numerical tools that will enable thorough and timely predictions of wind turbine wakes by reproducing modulations of the Reynolds stresses induced by VLSMs. This research project is comprised of three interrelated tasks.  First, there are two LIDAR measurement campaigns, the first one for a site over a relatively flat terrain in North Texas and a second one over a complex terrain.  The third task uses the resulting experimental data for modeling VLSM-induced modulations on wind turbine wakes through optimal tuning of turbulence closure models within an adjoint Reynolds-averaged Navier-Stokes framework.  This research project is helping to answer a number of key questions related to the morphology and energy content of VLSMs and how variable are they under different regimes of the atmospheric stability, the physical mechanisms governing generation of VLSMs and energy transport among coherent structures with different length-scales for ABL flows, and the role of land cover and topography in VLSM genesis and dynamics. The research project also aims to quantify the effects of the amplitude modulations induced by VLSMs on aerodynamic performance of utility-scale wind turbines and downstream evolution of wind turbine wakes.

por.por_cntn:
This project has advanced our understanding of the organization and energy contributions of coherent turbulent structures present in the atmospheric boundary layer (ABL) and their interactions with utility-scale wind turbines. The characterization and prediction of these turbulent processes is instrumental to maximize wind farm power capture and reduce turbine structural loads.

Particular attention has been paid to the investigation of wall-attached eddies, whose statistical features can be predicted through Townsend's attached eddy hypothesis (AEH), and very-large-scale motions (VLSMs), which are large energy-containing structures not encompassed in the AEH. The investigation of the energy content and dynamics of these turbulent structures is only possible for high Reynolds-number boundary layers, which has motivated the research strategy of this project by probing a neutrally-stratified atmospheric surface layer (ASL) with scanning wind light detection and ranging (LiDAR). Several challenges associated with this novel research strategy have been tackled and overcome, such as the reduced turbulence intensity measured with a wind LiDAR associated with the spatial averaging over each probe volume. To address this technical limitation, a data-driven technique has been proposed to achieve more accurate predictions of the energy content associated with different turbulent eddies [Puccioni & Iungo 2021]. Furthermore, probing the ASL requires adequate spatio-temporal resolution, which can only be achieved through the optimal design of the LiDAR scans. To this aim, the LiDAR statistical Barnes objective analysis (LiSBOA) technique has been developed [Letizia et al. 2021a, 2021b]. Among the various results achieved through the various LiDAR field campaigns, it is worth mentioning an analytical model proposed for the prediction of the linear coherence in the streamwise velocity associated with wall-attached eddies and VLSMs [Puccioni et al. 2023].

Several LiDAR field campaigns have been performed to characterize the interaction between the ABL and wind turbines, their wakes, and effects of the site topography [e.g., Iungo et al. 2018, Zhan et al. 2020a, 2020b, 2020c]. The data sets generated during the project have been leveraged to develop improved wind turbine wake models and optimize the design of wind farm layouts [Santhanagopalan et al. 2018a, 2018b, Santoni et al. 2018, 2020]. Among the different efforts performed on wind farm modeling, it is noteworthy to mention the Pseudo-2D RANS model [Letizia & Iungo 2022]. With this model, the evolution of the turbulent wind field across a wind farm is predicted by solving parabolically the RANS equations over a plane passing through the turbine hub heights, while the three-dimensionality of the flow is represented by injecting closure vertical turbulent fluxes. The RANS turbulence closure and the thrust force induced by the wind turbine rotors have been modeled with a data-driven approach by leveraging the LiDAR data and the turbine operational data. The Pseudo-2D RANS provides a good trade-off between computational costs and accuracy in modeling wind farm operations by solving parabolically the RANS equations while enhancing accuracy in flow and power predictions through its data-driven nature.

More innovative modeling strategies have been explored during the project using machine learning. LiDAR measurements of wind turbine wakes have been interrogated through a k-means algorithm to cluster the wake variability for different atmospheric regimes and turbine operative conditions [Maulik et al. 2021]. The cluster centers, which represent the typical realizations of the wakes, are leveraged to predict wake variability as a function of the incoming wind speed and turbulence intensity by using a random forest algorithm [Iungo et al. 2022]. Gaussian process modeling has also been explored to provide an alternative to physics-based simulations ensuring accuracy in wake predictions, yet with highly-reduced computational costs [Renganathan et al. 2022].

This project has generated 11 journal papers and 6 conference papers, while numerous presentations have been delivered to various professional meetings of the turbulence and wind energy research communities. Mentoring and training have been provided to 5 Ph.D. students, 4 M.Sc. students, and 8 undergraduate students supported through the NSF REU program. The majority of the students are currently working for national laboratories and leading companies in wind energy.

Several outreach activities have been performed during the execution of the project, such as the wind energy exhibit organized in 2020 at the UTD BLAST wind tunnel for the 5th and 6th graders of the Yale elementary school of Richardson, TX. During the project, we developed and deployed an exhibit encompassing several down-scaled wind turbine models, a wind generator, and posters about atmospheric turbulence and wind energy. In 2018, this exhibit was presented at the Perot Museum in Dallas to over 3,500 students from 136 ZIP codes in Texas. On that occasion, the project PI delivered a TED talk about atmospheric turbulence and wind energy. The exhibit has been deployed in rotation to various schools and public libraries of the DFW metroplex area, as well as in 2019 for the National Engineers week, where more than 2,500 students attended the event.
